text: {"grade": 0, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the response to claim that environmental obligations cannot form the basis of any counterclaim under international law. The candidate answer explicitly discusses the admissibility of domestic law counterclaims (Section I.C.3), noting they are 'Most controversial and usually rejected' but then cites *Perenco v. Ecuador* where a tribunal accepted jurisdiction over a domestic environmental law counterclaim and awarded damages. The response does not make the absolute claim that environmental obligations *cannot* form the basis of a counterclaim; rather, it analyzes the varying judicial practice regarding domestic law counterclaims, acknowledging that some tribunals have accepted them.", "criterion_id": "4039082c-276f-47cd-ad4b-06fd8b91be97"}
